Then I restored it with medicines and it was consolidated quickly and healed: and this iteration was not necessary for the operation and section of it, except on account of the debilitation of the sick person, and his lack of tolerance, and my fear for him in regard to death: because he was threatened by a bad syncopes at every hour from excessive evacuation.
Sanatus est ergo sanatione integra: et nata est in loco ossis caro dura, et bona facta est dispositio in corpore suo, et rediit uirtus eius: et conuersatus est in dispositionibus suis: et non fecit ei contrarietatem in ambulatione nocumentum omnino.	He was therefore restored by complete healing: and a hard, good flesh grew in the place of the bone, and a good arrangement was made in his body, and his strength returned: and he regained his normal disposition: and there was no harm to him at all in his walking.
Si autem os eminens in loco corporis iam fractum est: tunc oportet ut serres ipsum, secundum hunc modum: et est: ut accipias ligamentum, et stringe ipsum in extremitate ossis eminentis: et praecipe alicui, qui extendat ipsum ad sursum: et pone ligamentum aliud ex lana grossius ligamento primo.	If however the prominent bone is already broken in the body's location: then it is necessary to stitch it up, in this way: and this is: take a bandage, and tie it at the end of the prominent bone: and appoint someone to stretch it upwards: and place another bandage of coarse wool over the first bandage.
Deinde liga ipsum super carne, quae est suh osse: et extende extremitatem eius, ut trahas carnem ad inferiora: et tu detegis carnem super locum quem uis serrare, ut non laedat Serra carnem.	Then bind the bandage over the flesh that is near the bone: and stretch out its end so as to pull the flesh down towards the lower part: and you shall uncover the flesh above the place which you wish to suture, so that the suture does not harm the flesh.
Pone lignum, aut tabulam sub osse inferius decenter: quoniam quando facis illud, non prohibetur quin secet carnem corruptam.	Place a stick or board under the bone below decently: because when you do that, it is not prevented from cutting corrupted flesh.
Et oportet ut sit Serratura super locum corruptum parumper, ut non sit in concauitate ossis corruptio: et non appareat in apparitione sua sensui, et cogat ad Serraturam sui uice alia.	And it is necessary that the suture be placed above the corrupted area for a little while, so that there is not corruption of the bone in its concavity: and does not appear to the sense, and causes another suture to take its place.
Quod si os est corruptum, et non est eminens, imo continuatur pars eius cum parte: et corruptio est in medio eius, aut in parte ipsius: tunc detege carnem ab omnibus partibus totam.	What if the bone is corrupted and not prominent, but is continuous with another part of it; and the corruption is in its middle or in one of its parts: then remove the flesh from all its parts altogether.
Deinde pone lignum inferius.	Then place a stick below.
Postea serra illud ex parte prima, ubi est corruptio, donec continuetur Serratura ex parte altera: et sit Serratura secundum longitudinem a corruptione parumper, secundum quod diximus.	Afterwards, cut that from the first part where there is corruption, until the suture is continuous from the other side; and let the suture be according to the length, a little bit away from the corruption, as we said.
Quod si corruptio est in iunctura, incide ipsam iuncturam corruptam, et serra os ubi continuatur ex parte altera.	What if the corruption is at the joint, cut out the corrupted joint and then cut the bone where it continues on the other side.
Si uero corruptio est in continuatione duarum iuncturarum, tunc non est in ea ingenium nisi abrasio.	If however the corruption is in the continuation of two joints, then there is no skill needed except for scraping away.
Quod si corruptio est in pectine manus, aut in pectine pedis: tunc res in eo est difficilis ualde.	What if the corruption is in the breastbone of the hand or in the breastbone of the foot: then there is great difficulty in it.
Verum oportet, ut inquiras corruptionem qualiter appareat tibi.	But it is necessary that you investigate how the corruption appears to you.
Et abradas eam, et mundes ipsam secundum quamcunque dispositionem tibi possibile est, et cum quocunque ingenio rectificatur tibi: quando non facit tibi contrarietatem Vena, aut Neruus.	And scrape it clean, and purify it according to any arrangement possible for you, and with whatever skill is available to you; when it does not make a contradiction in the Vein, or Nerve.
Et scias quod incisoria, et Serrae ad incidendum ista ossa sunt multa, secundum situm ossium, et praparationem eorum, et ipsorum grossitudinem, et subtilitatem eorum, et magnitudinem, et paruitatem ipsorum, et duriciem ipsorum, et eorum raritatem.	And know that incisors and saws for cutting those bones are many, according to the location of the bones, and their preparation, and their thickness, and subtlety, and magnitude, and smallness, and hardness, and rarity.
Quapropter oportet, ut praepares omni speciei operationis instrumentum conueniens ad illam operationem.	Therefore, it is necessary to prepare the suitable instrument for every kind of operation.
Et scias, quod operationes istae significant tibi super speciem instrumenti quo indiges, quando tecum est studium longum.	And know that these operations signify to you according to the type of instrument which you need, when with you is a long study.
Et cognitio modorum huius artis, testimonium modorum aegritudinum: tunc enim iam inuenies per teipsum illud quod conuenit ei ex instrumentis ad omnem infirmitatem.	And the knowledge of the methods of this art is a testimony to the methods of diseases: then indeed you will find within yourself what suits each infirmity from the instruments.
Et ego sum firmans tibi in ultimo huius capituli numerum instrumentorum, quae pones exempla super quae incides, et probationem qua experiaris super alia.	And I am setting forth for you at the end of this chapter the number of instruments which you will put examples on to cut into, and a proof by which you will test other things.
Forma Serrae.	Saw form.
Forma alterius Serrae.	Form of another saw.
Forma Serrae alterius.	Form of another saw.
Forma Serrae alterius.	Form of yet another saw.
Haec forma Serrae depicta, sit decenter facta.	This form of the saw is depicted, made with precision.
Fiat arcus eius superior, acuitas eius ex ferro: et manubrium eius ex buxo, et sit pyramidale decenter factum.	Let its upper curve be made of a bow, its edge sharp from iron; and let its handle be made of boxwood, and let it be well-proportioned in the shape of a pyramid.
Forma Rasorii iuncturarum.	Razor form for joints.
Sit caput huius Rasorii, secundum formam capitis claui stellati: et puncta eius sint secundum formam punctorum elischetfegi.	Let the head of this razor be shaped like the head of a star-shaped awl; and let its points be shaped like those of an engraver's tool.
Et non conuenit, nisi ut fricentur cum eo capita iuncturarum, quando corrumpuntur, aut os amplum, et magnum est.	And it is not suitable, unless the heads of joints are rubbed with it when they are corrupted, or a large and great bone.
Forma maioris Rasorii.	Greater Razor form.
Forma medii Rasorii.	The form of the middle razor.
Forma Rasorii lati.	The form of the broad razor.
Forma Rasorii in quo est concauitas.	The form of the razor in which there is concavity.
Forma Rasorii alterius subtilis.	The form of the other subtle razor.
Forma Rasorii alterius curuatae extremitatis.	The form of the other curved extremity razor.
Forma Rasorii parui, subtilis tentae.	The form of the small subtle probe.
Forma Rasorii cum quo inciduntur ossa.	The form of the razor with which bones are cut.
Forma etiam Rasorii magni.	The form also of the great razor.
Hoc similatur Radio, et extremitas est sicut Serra: exhibetur in locis multis ex rasione ossium.	This resembles a saw, and its extremity is like a file: it is shown in many places for the removal of bones.
Forma Rasorii quod conuenit ad rasionem eius quod perforatum est ex ossibus.	The form of the razor which is suitable for the removal of that which has been perforated from bones.
Extremitas eius triangula, acutarum est extremitatum.	Its extremity is triangular, and sharp at its edges.
Fit ex Indi.	It comes from India.
Et similiter oportet, ut fiant omnia quae diximus ex Rasoriis, et Incisoriis, et Serris.	And similarly all the things we have said should be made of Razors, and Knives, and Files.
¶ De incisione extremitatum, et Serratura ossium.	On the cutting off of extremities, and on the sawing of bones.
Caput LXXXIX.	Chapter 89.
Putrefiunt extremitates, aut ex caussa extrinseca, aut intrinseca.	They putrefy due to an external or internal cause.
Cum ergo medicatus fueris illam corruptionem curatione medicinarum, et non confert curatio: et uides corruptionem incidere in membrum, quam non repercutit aliquid: tunc oportet ut incidas illud membrum usque ubi consequitu corruptio, ut euadat infirmus per illud a morte, aut a malicia quae est maior defectu membri.	Therefore, when you have treated the corruption with medical remedies and the cure does not take effect: and you see the corruption occurring in a member which does not respond to anything; then it is necessary that you cut off that member as far as the corruption extends, so that the sick person may escape through that member from death or from a greater defect of the member.
Et signum cui accidit illud est, quod denigratur membrum, donec putetur: quod ignis combussit ipsum, aut putrefit post nigredinem: donec inciditur illa putredo usque ad illud quod sequitur illud membrum, et serpit in totum corpus.	And the sign that this happens is that the member becomes blackened until it rots: or if fire has consumed it, or it has putrefied after blackening: until the putridity reaches as far as the following bone and spreads throughout the entire body.
Propera ergo cum incisione eius, et similiter si caussa corruptionis est a percussione quorundam uenenosorum: sicut scorpionis marini, et uiperae, et rutellae, et similium.	Therefore, proceed with the incision of it, and similarly if the cause of corruption is due to the striking of certain veneneous things, such as the sea scorpion, viper, adder, and similar.
Si ergo corruptio, aut percussio est in extremitate digiti, tunc incide digitum, et non des spacium corruptioni, ut incedat usque ad reliquam manum.	If therefore a corruption or percussion is at the end of the finger, then cut off the finger and do not leave space for the corruption to spread, until it reaches the rest of the hand.
Et similiter si accidit in manu, tunc incide eam ex radice focilis, et non des spacium corruptioni, donec capiat in focili brachii.	And similarly if it happens in the hand, then cut it off from the wrist and do not leave space for the corruption, until it reaches the armpit of the arm.
Et si inuadit in eo, tunc incide brachium apud cubitum in iunctura sua.	And if it spreads into that, then cut off the arm at the elbow joint.
Si autem pertransit corruptio, et uides eum circiter cubitum: tunc in illo est mors infirmi.	But if corruption passes through and you see him about the elbow: then it is the death of the infirm person.
Et administrare praeter illud ex curatione, est quantitas uirtus.	And to apply something beyond that from a cure, is a quantity of power.
Et similiter fac de pede, quando inuadit corruptio in digito, tunc incide ipsum apud unum nodorum: et si capit in pectine pedis, tunc incide pedem totum.	And similarly do the same for the foot, when corruption spreads into a toe, then cut it off at one of the joints; and if it reaches to the shinbone, then cut off the whole foot.
Si autem ascendit ad genu, tunc incide crus apud iuncturam genu.	But if it ascends to the knee, then cut off the leg at the knee joint.
Quod si corruptio iam peruenit supra genu, tunc non est in ea ingenium, nisi dimissio, et relinquere infirmum morti.	What if corruption has already reached above the knee, then there is no remedy for it except death, and to leave the sick person to die.
Et modus incidendi membrum, aut serrandi ipsum est, ut stringas ligamentum in inferiori, quem uis incidere: et stringe ligamentum aliud supra locum.	And the method of cutting off a limb or sawing it is to tie the ligament at the lower part which you wish to cut off: and tie another ligament above that place.
Et extendat minister ligamentum unum ad inferiora: et extendat minister aliud ligamentum superius ad sursum.	And have one assistant stretch out a ligament down below: and have another assistant stretch out the other ligament up above.
Et tu separa carnem quae est inter duo ligamenta, cum Spatumili lato, donec detegatur caro tota.	And you separate the flesh that is between the two ligaments, with a broad spatula, until the whole flesh is uncovered.
Deinde incidatur, aut serretur.	Then it should be cut or sawed.
Et oportet, ut ponas ab omnibus partibus pannum lini, et non tangat Serra locum sanum: et accidat infirmo laesio addita, et apostema calidum.	And it is necessary to place a linen cloth around all parts, and not have the saw touch a healthy area; lest an additional injury befall the sick person, and a hot abscess occur.
Si autem accidat fluxus sanguinis interius dum operaris, tunc cauteriza locum uelociter: aut pone super ipsum quosdam pulueres abscindentes sanguinem.	But if bleeding occurs internally while you are operating, then cauterize the area quickly or place some powder above it that absorbs blood.
Deinde redi ad medicationem tuam, donec compleatur.	Then return to your treatment until it is complete.
Deinde liga membrum uulneratum cum ligamento conueniente ei, et cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Then bind the wounded member with a suitable bandage and care for it until it heals.
Et ego narro tibi quod accidit uiro in pede suo, hoc idem accidens quod narro tibi.	And I will tell you what happened to a man on his foot, the same thing that is happening to him.
Quod est, quia accidit in pede suo nigredo, cum adustione quae assimilatur combustioni ignis: et corruptio illa in primis accidit in digito suo, donec coepit pedem totum.	What is this? Because a blackening occurred on his foot, with a burning that resembles the combustion of fire: and that corruption first occurred on his toe, until it spread to his entire foot.
Properauit ergo uir ex seipso, postquam uidit corruptionem incidere in membro cum uehementia eius, quod inuenit ex dolore, et adustione eius: et incidit ipsum apud iuncturam, et sanatus est.	Therefore the man took care of himself after he saw corruption spreading on his member with its swelling, which he found to be caused by pain and burning; and it happened that he was healed at the joint.
Et postquam praeteriit ei tempus longum, accidit ei illa eadem corruptio in digito manus suae indice.	And after a long time had passed, the same corruption occurred on his index finger of his hand.
Venit ergo ad me, et conatus sum recuperare illam superfluitatem cum eo quod posui super manum ex medicinis post mundificationem corporis eius: et non repercussa est superfluitas, et coepit incedere in digitum alium: donec coepit coruptio in manum.	So he came to me and I tried to remove the excess with him after applying medicines on his body once it was cleansed; and the excess did not recur, but began to spread to another finger, until corruption began to spread throughout his hand.
Vocauit ergo me, ad incidendum manum eius: et nolui illud, sperans ex me super repercussionem illius superfluitatis: et timui etiam super ipsum apud incisionem manus eius mortem.	So he called on me to cut open his hand: and I refused, hoping that the excess would recur spontaneously; and I was also afraid of death at the point of incision in his hand.
Quoniam uirtus uiri erat super casum.	Because the man's strength was greater than the accident.
Postquam ergo desperauit de me, reuersus est ad terram suam: et peruenit ad me de eo, quia properauit, et incidit manum suam totam: et sanatus est.	Afterward, since he had given up on me, he returned to his land and came back to me about it, because he was in a hurry and cut open his entire hand; and he was healed.
Et non attuli hanc narrationem, nisi ut sit adiutorium super illud quod cadit de genere huius aegritudinis: et ut sit significatio qua significetur, et secundum quam agatur.	And I did not narrate this story, unless it is to be a help for that which falls under the category of this illness; and to signify what should be signified, and according to how one should act.
¶ De cura Sinuum, et qualitate clisterizationis cum medicinis.	Of the treatment of wounds, and the quality of cleansing with medicines.
Caput XC.	Chapter 90.
Quando accidit apostema in quibusdam membris carnosis, et prolongatur spacium apostematis, donec collectionem facit saniei: deinde rumpitur, aut perforatur, et egreditur quod in eo est ex sanie, et remanet locus uacuus quasi sit uas: et cutis quae est super ipsum sicut pannus qui iam subtiliatus est: et non peruenit ad ultimum in corruptione sua, neque imprimit in os, neque in neruum, neque in ligamentum: meretur ut nominetur Sinus: et non nominatur Fistula: uerumtamen si prolongatur spacium eius, donec imprimat corruptio in aliquid horum membrorum, tunc nominatur Fistula, aut zuken.	Here is the translation:
Et cura eius est, ut incidas illam cutem totam sicut reuoluitur: et praecipue quando subtiliata est, et facta sicut pannus: et confidis quia non aaehaeret cum loco, propter corruptionem suam.	And the treatment for this is to cut off that skin entirely as it has rolled back: and especially when it has been thinned out and become like a cloth: and you can trust that it will not reunite with its location due to its own corruption.
Si autem speras quod adhaereat cutis, et non consequitur ex eo corruptio illa ultima consecutione: et si in cute est spissitudo ex carne, tunc cura ipsum cum Clisteri: et est, ut consideres ad Sinum.	But if you hope that the skin will stick together and it does not result from that last corruption; and if there is a thickness of flesh under the skin, then treat it with a poultice and is, to consider the navel.
Tunc si est magnus, et pus quod emittitur ex eo est foetidi odoris: tunc clisteriza ipsum cum medicamine aegyptio, quod est aceti, et olei, et ziniar, partes recipiens aequales, aggregentur in uase: et decoquantur super ignem, donec rubeat medicamen: et ueniat in spissitudinem mellis.	Then if it is large and the pus that is discharged from it has a foul odor: then treat it with a poultice made of Egyptian medicine, which is vinegar, oil, and zinar, taking equal parts, mixed together in a vessel: and let them simmer over fire until the medicine becomes thick like honey.
Deinde accipe ex eo quod tibi necesse est: et dissolue ipsum cum aqua et melle, et clisteriza cum eo Sinum: et stringe orificium eius, et dimitte medicinam in eo ad quantitatem duarum horarum.	Then take from it what is necessary for you: and dissolve it with water and honey, and treat the navel with it: and close up its opening, and leave the medicine in it for a period of two hours.
Deinde extrahe ipsum cum expressione: fac illud diebus tot, donec mundificetur Sinus, et remoueatur foetor.	Then draw out what remains with expression: make this happen every day until the navel is purified and the foul odor is removed.
Et quandoque clisterizatur cum aqua cineris, quando non est tibi praesens hoc medicamen: et est, ut accipias cinerem lignorum uitis, aut cinerem ex lignis ilicis: et proiicias super eam aquam.	And sometimes treat it with ash water when this medicine is not available to you: and take the ash of vine wood or ash from ilex trees: and pour water over it.
Deinde cola eam, et clisteriza cum ea, donec confidas quod Sinus iam ablutus est.	Then soak it in that, and treat with it, until you are confident that the navel is already cleansed.
Quod si infirmo non est tolerantia super medicamen aegyptium, neque aquam cineris, tunc clisteriza ipsum cum aqua et melle, cui iam permixtum est aliquid ex ziniar contrito.	And if the patient is not tolerant of Egyptian medicine or ash water, then treat it with water and honey to which something from crushed zinar has been mixed.
Aut clisteriza ipsum cum melle et uino permixtis, quoniam de proprietate mellis est, ut mundificet, et abluat: et uinum facit adhaerere Sinum, praecipue quando in uino est superfluitas stipticitatis et siccitatis.	Or treat it with honey and wine mixed together, because of the property of honey that it cleanses and washes: and wine makes the navel stick together, especially when there is an excess of astringency and dryness in the wine.
Cum facis illud aliquotiens, et confidis quod Sinus corruptio iam remota est: tunc clisteriza ipsum cum eo quod facit nasci carnem in eo.	When you do that thing many times and trust that corruption of the sinus is now removed: then cleanse it with what makes flesh grow in it.
Et est, ut accipias ex emplastro dyafinicon: et dissoluas ipsum cum oleo rosato, et uino stiptico: aut clisteriza ipsum cum quibusdam medicinis, et unguentis aliis, quorum proprietates scripsi in tractatu unguentorum.	And it is, that you take from diaphrenic plaster: and dissolve it with rose oil, and astringent wine: or cleanse it with certain medicines, and other ointments, the properties of which I wrote in the treatise on ointments.
Quod si orificium Sinus est strictum, in quo non capit cannula clisteris: tunc amplifica ipsum cum ferro parumper: aut pone in ipso licinium inuolutum in unguento aegyptio, aut in unguento basilicon, donec amplificetur.	But if the orifice of the sinus is narrow, into which the cannula of the cleanse does not fit: then dilate it with a small iron instrument: or put a linen cloth wrapped in Egyptian ointment, or Basilikon ointment, until it is dilated.
Et similiter si est orificium etiam amplum, tunc aggrega labia eius cum sutura: et dimitte ex eo quantitatem in quam ingrediatur clistere sine additione.	And similarly if the orifice is also wide, then bring together its lips with a suture: and let it be free from that amount which the cleanse can enter without addition.
Et similiter si orificium eius ex quo currit pus, est eleuatum ad superiora: tunc seca ipsum in depressiori loco qui est in ipso, ut currat ex eo pus usque inferius: quoniam pus quando coartatur in profunditate Sinus, prohibet carnem generari in eo.	And similarly if the orifice from which pus runs is elevated to above: then cut it in a lower place that is in it, so that pus may flow out of it downwards: for pus when constricted in the depth of the sinus prevents flesh from being generated in it.
Quod si non est tibi possibile secare Sinum circiter inferius eius secundum quod uis: tunc conare, ut praepares membrum praeparatione qua currat ex eo pus cum facilitate secundum quod praeparatur tibi.	And if it is not possible for you to cut the sinus around its lower part as you wish: then try to prepare the member with a preparation by which pus may flow out of it easily as it is prepared for you.
Conare, ut non retineatur in eo aliquid ex pus omnino: et accipe medicinas consolidatiuas quae ponuntur super signum, conuenientes ad illud quod uis.	Try to make sure that nothing at all of the pus is retained in it: and take consolidating medicines which are placed on a sign, corresponding to what you wish.
Et extende eas super pannum lini.	And spread them over a linen cloth.
Et sit pannus tantae quantitatis, qua fiat communicatio totius Sinus.	And let the cloth be of such a size that it may be in contact with the whole sinus.
Deinde incide cum forficibus in directo orificii Sinus foramen, amplius orificio Sinus parumper.	Then cut with forceps into the straight orifice of the sinus, making the opening a little wider than the orifice of the sinus.
Deinde extende ex unguentis lenibus super pannum alium, secundum quantitatem foraminis: et pone eum super ipsum positione longinqua ab orificio Sinus, ut alleuietur exitus pus ex eo: et non auferas pannum magnum, nisi post dies aliquos uice una.	Then spread a layer of soft ointment over another cloth, according to the size of the opening; and place it on top in a distant position from the orifice of the sinus, so that the exit of pus may be eased out: and do not remove the cloth until several days have passed.
Ille autem qui est super orificium Sinus, est ille quem remoues in omni hora, ut egrediatur quod aggregatur in eo ex pus: et ut scias, an illud quod currit ex eo uirus, est multum, aut parum: aut digestum, aut indigestum.	He who is above the opening of the sinus, is he whom you remove every hour, so that what gathers in it from pus may go out: and to know whether that which flows out of it is much or little, or digested or undigested.
Et cum hoc iterum considera locum Sinus ipsius, an in ipso sentiat dominus eius dolorem, aut non sit in eo dolor, et an sit in eo apostema, aut non sit in eo apostema.	And when you have considered this again, look at the place of the sinus itself: whether its lord feels pain in it or does not feel pain in it; and whether there is an apostema in it or not.
Cum ergo protenditur medicatio tua taliter, et uides materiam quae egreditur super orificium Sinus, tunc scias, quod Sinus iam adhaeret, aut approximat adhaerentiae: tunc ergo solue ipsum in mane, aut in tertio die: et quando soluis uulnus, tunc permuta pannum alium, et renoua unguentum.	So when your treatment is proceeding thus and you see the matter that flows out above the opening of the sinus, then you will know that the sinus has already adhered or approaches adhesion: then therefore dissolve it in the morning or on the third day; and when you dissolve the wound, then change the cloth for another one, and renew the ointment.
Si autem egreditur ex Sinu post spacium longum uirus subtile, tunc non desperes de adhaerentia eius, nam sanatio eius appropinquat, quoniam ex hominibus sunt qui tardant generationem carnis in uulneribus suis, et ex eis sunt qui agunt econtrario illius.	But if there flows from the sinus after a long time a subtle pus, then do not despair of its adhesion, for its healing is approaching, because among men are those who slow down the formation of flesh in their wounds and among them are those who act contrary to it.
Si autem egreditur ex Sinu post dies multos pus indigestum, tunc scias quod sinus non adhaeret.	But if there flows from the sinus after many days an undigested pus, then you will know that the sinus is not adhering.
Si ergo tardatur adhaerentia Sinus, et prolongatur res eius: tunc adde in exiccatione medicinarum, uerum faciant medici, ut sint medicinae in substantia sua humidae, et in uirtute sua siccae: sicut unguentum dyafinicon, quando additur in eo superfluitas additionis ex zegi.	So if the adhesion of the sinus is delayed and its process prolonged: then add to the drying remedy, let the physicians truly do so, that the medicine be in its substance humid and in its virtue dry: just as diaphrenic ointment, when something in excess is added to it from zegi.
Et ex magis ultimo quo curatur, est, ut accipias unguentum dyafinicon, et soluatur cum oleo rosato, et roretur super ipsum uinum antiquum aequale in substantia sua.	And from the last remedy used for healing, it is to take diaphrenic ointment and dissolve it with rose oil, and sprinkle over it ancient wine equal in its substance.
Deinde confice ipsum cum eo, et utere ipso.	Then compress it with that, and use it.
Et iam facit simile huic actioni, quando non est tibi praesens unguentum dyafinicon, mel, quando decoquis ipsum, donec ingrossetur, et uteris eo.	And now it does the same thing when you do not have diaphrenic ointment available, use honey instead, when you cook it until it thickens, and use it.
Aut accipe myrrham, et aloen, et olibanum: tere totum, et pulueriza illud super mel dum est super ignem.	Take myrrh, and aloes, and frankincense: grind the whole, and powderize that over honey while it is above the fire.
Deinde line super ipsum pannum, et stringe ipsum super Sinum: et line cum melle quod decoquisti, donec ingrossatum est: et pulueriza super ipsum species, et pone super ipsum pannum, et stringe eum.	Then pour the mixture over the cloth, and bind it on the breast; and pour with honey that you have cooked, until it has thickened; and powderize over the surface, and put it on the cloth, and bind it.
Et quandoque administratur in illo aristolochia longa, et radices lilii coelestis, et est lilium: et farina herbi, et centaurea.	And sometimes it is administered with Aristolochia longa, and roots of the heavenly lily, which is lily; and farina of herbs, and Centaurea.
Utere eis simplicibus, aut aggregatis, tere ea, et cribella ipsa: et pulueriza super mel quod narraui, et utere eo.	Use them in simples or compound remedies, grind those, and sift them out; and powderize over the honey that I mentioned, and use it.
Quod si prolongatur res Sinus, et non sanatur hac curatione: tunc scias, quod in profundo eius est corruptio: aut iam facit impressionem in ossibus, aut in reliquis membris duris, aut ligamentis: tunc cura ipsum curatione Fistularum, secundum quod praemissum est.	But if the breast abscess prolongs and is not healed by this treatment: then you will know that there is corruption deep within it; or it is already making an impression on the bones, or in other hard parts of the body, or ligaments; then treat it with the cure for fistulas, as was previously mentioned.
¶ De cura Panaritii et unguis attritae, et incisione digiti additi, et sectione.	Of the treatment of paronychia and the attrition of the nail, with addition of finger incision and section.
Caput XCI.	Page 91.
Panaritium est apostema quod nascitur sub ungue pollicis manus, aut pedis: et fortasse nascitur in reliquis digitis.	Paronychia is an abscess that arises under the nail of the thumb or foot, or perhaps in other fingers.
Cum ergo prolongatur res eius, et negligitur curato eius, et apostematur apostemate calido: aut corrumpitur, et emittit pus, donec corrodit radicem unguis: et fortasse corrumpit eam totam, et fortasse peruenit corruptio ad os, donec est ei odor foetidus: et fit extremitas digiti lata, et fit color eius fuscus.	When therefore the abscess prolongs and is neglected and not cured, and becomes a hot apostema: or it corrupts and discharges pus, until it eats away the root of the nail; and perhaps it corrupts the whole of it, and perhaps corruption reaches to the bone, until it has a foul odor: and the end of the finger becomes wide, and its color becomes dark.
Quando ergo tu curas ipsum, cum eo quod diximus in diuisione, et non confert curatio tua: tunc oportet ut incidas cum ferro totam superfluitatem quae remansit ex ungue.	When therefore you cure it with what we said in the division, and your treatment does not help: then it is necessary that you cut off the whole excess that remains from the nail.
Deinde cauteriza uulnus post illud.	Then cauterize the wound after that.
Cauterium enim iuuatiuum est ualde.	A cauterizing instrument is very helpful.
Si uero os est sanum, et est unguis etiam sana, et additiones uacuae unguis iam comprimunt carnem ad interiora, et incipiunt pungere ipsam, et laedunt eam: tunc oportet ut ponas Radium subtilem sub angulo unguis quae pungit carnem, et impelle eam sursum: et incide eam carnem cum facilitate, et pone super illud quod remanet de carne ex medicinis comburentibus, corrosiuis, donec remoueatur totum eius.	If the bone is sound and the nail also sound, and the additions of the nail are pressing upon the flesh to the inside, and begin to pierce it, and hurt it: then you must place a thin Radiatum under the angle of the nail that is piercing the flesh, and push it upwards: and cut through the flesh with ease, and place above what remains of the flesh from medicines burning, corrosive, until all is removed.
Deinde cura illud cum unguentis, donec sanetur.	Then care for that wound with ointments, until it heals.
Si autem corruptio iam imprimit in os, tunc oportet ut incidas illud os, et extrahas ipsum: non enim sanatur unquam dum permanet in eo os corruptum.	But if corruption has already taken hold in the bone, then it is necessary to cut out that bone and remove it: for it will never heal as long as the corrupted bone remains.
Quod si uides corrosionem et corruptionem incedere in digitum, tunc incide eum in uno nodorum, secundum quod praemissa est eius rememoratio.	If you see corrosion and corruption spreading in a finger, then cut it off at one of the joints, according to what has been previously mentioned about its recollection.
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Then care for that part, until it heals.
Si autem accidat ungui attritio, aut percussio: et contingit in ea dolor uehemens, tunc oportet ut phlebotomes infirmum in primis.	If however a finger is bruised or struck: and there occurs in it a vehement pain, then it is necessary to bleed the patient first.
Deinde seca unguem cum Spatumili acuto sectione transuersa de sursum ad uisum.	Then cut off the finger with a sharp razor blade, making a transverse incision from above to below.
Et custodi, ne sectio perueniat ad carnem quae est sub ungue, nam tu facies accidere per illud super infirmum dolorem uehementem, et erit caussa ad natiuitatem carnis additae in loco.	And take care not to cut through the flesh that is under the nail, for you will bring about a severe pain upon the patient, and it will be a cause of added flesh growth in that place.
Deinde cura locum cum eo quod sedat dolores.	Then care for the place with what soothes pains.
Digitus uero additus qui nascitur in quibusdam manibus hominum, fortasse est carnosus totus: et fortasse sunt in quibusdam eorum ossa, et fortasse est in eo unguis: et quidam eorum nascitur in radice iuncturae, aut est natiuitas eius in quibusdam nodis digiti.	The added finger that grows on some people's hands is perhaps entirely fleshy: and perhaps there are bones in some of them, and perhaps there is a nail in it: and some of them grow from the root of the joint or at one of the finger joints.
Ille ergo qui nascitur in quibusdam nodis digiti, non mouetur: et ille qui nascitur apud iuncturam digiti, fortasse mouetur.	Therefore, that which grows from some of the finger joints does not move: and that which grows at the joint of the finger, perhaps moves.
Eius ergo qui ex eis est carnosus, sectio eius facilis est.	Therefore, the one who is fleshy among them has an easy incision.
Quod est, ut incidas ipsum apud radicem suam cum Spatumili lato.	What there is to cut it at its root with a broad spatula.
Eius autem cuius natiuitas est in radice iuncturae curatio, est difficilis.	However, the one whose birth is in the joint's union is difficult to cure.
Abstine ergo ab incisione eius.	So then abstain from cutting it.
In illo uero qui nascitur in digito apud ultimum nodorum, tunc oportet ut incidas in primis carnem eius incisione rotunda usque ad os.	In that one who is born on the finger at the last joints, then it is necessary to cut through its first flesh with a round incision up to the bone.
Deinde serra os cum una illarum Serrarum conuenientium ad illud.	Then file the bone with one of those files that are suitable for it.
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Then take care of it until it heals.
Consolidatio autem quae accidit digitis adinuicem, multotiens accidit aut ex natiuitate hominis, id est, nascitur cum eo, aut a consolidatione uulneris, aut combustione ignis, et similibus.	However, the consolidation that occurs on fingers one by one often happens either because of a person's birth, that is, it is born with him, or from the consolidation of a wound, or burning by fire, and similar things.
Oportet ergo ut seces illam consolidationem, donec redeant digiti secundum formam suam naturalem.	It is necessary then to cut off that consolidation until the fingers return to their natural shape.
Deinde pone inter eos licinia, aut pannos infusos in oleo rosato: ut non consolidentur uelociter, et separa inter eos: aut pone inter eos laminam plumbi subtilem, donec consolidetur locus secundum quod oportet.	Then place between them linen or cloth soaked in rose oil: so that they do not consolidate quickly, and separate between them: or place between them a thin lead plate, until the location consolidates as it should.
Et similiter si accidat consolidatio quibusdam digitis cum palma, tunc seca illam consolidationem, secundum quod praeparatur et conuenit figurae membri.	And similarly if a consolidation occurs on some fingers with the palm, then cut off that consolidation according to how it is prepared and fits the figure of the member.
¶ De incisione Vitium.	De incisione Vitium.
Caput XCII.	Caput XCII.
Uites sunt Venae inuolutae, grossae, plenae superfluitatibus melancholicis quae accidunt in pluribus membris corporis: et plurimum euentus earum est in cruribus, praecipue in cruribus iter agentium et laborantium, et portantium.	There are veins that are twisted, thick, and full of superfluous melancholic substances which occur in many parts of the body: and most of them happen in legs, particularly in legs of travelers and workers, and those who carry loads.
Oportet ergo ut administres excussionem corporis ex cholera nigra aliquotiens excussione forti.	Therefore it is necessary to apply a purgation of the body with black cholera several times using strong cleansing.
Deinde phlebotoma patientis eas basilicam.	Then perform venesection on the patient's basilica vein.
Curatio uero earum cum ferro, est secundum duos modos.	The cure of those things with iron is according to two methods.
Vnus eorum est, ut secentur, et extrahatur sanguis niger.	One of them is that they are cauterized and black blood is removed.
Et modus alter est, ut eleuetur Vena, et extrahatur tota.	And the other method is that a vein is raised up and all [of it] is removed.
Sectio uero eius est secundum hunc modum.	The section of it is according to this method.
Embroca crus in primis cum aqua calida multum, donec resoluatur sanguis grossus faeculentus.	He binds the leg first with hot water a great deal, until the thick, bloody pus is dissolved.
Deinde stringe crus infirmi a superiori parte coxae eius, usque ad inferiorem partem genu cum uitta.	Then bind the weak leg from the upper part of his hip down to the lower part of the knee with a bandage.
Deinde seca uenam in loco uno, aut duobus, aut tribus sectione ampla.	Then cut the vein in one place, or two, or three, making a wide incision.
Deinde eleua, id est, extrahe sanguinem in manu tua ab inferiori parte cruris, usque ad sursum, et a superiori oportet ut phlebotomes infirmum in primis.	Then lift it, that is, remove the blood from your hand from the lower part of the leg up to above, and you should bleed the patient first.
Deinde seca unguem cum usque inferius: donec egrediatur ex sanguine quantitas quam uides sufficere, et quam tolerat uirtus infirmi.	Then cut the fingernail down to the bottom: until a quantity of blood emerges that you see is sufficient and which the patient's strength can tolerate.
Postea liga eam: et praecipe ei, ut abstineat a cibis generantibus choleram nigram: et itera euacuationem et phlebotomiam, quando implentur Venae, et nocet illud infirmo.	Afterwards bind it up and tell him to refrain from foods that cause black bile: and repeat the evacuation and bloodletting when the veins are full and it causes harm to the patient.
Eleuatio autem eius est secundum hunc modum.	The elevation of it is according to this method.
Rade crus infirmi, si in ea sunt pili multi.	Shave the weak leg, if there are many hairs on it.
Deinde intromitte ipsum in balneum: aut embroca ipsum in crure eius cum aqua calida, donec rubeat, et exuberentur Venae: aut exercitetur exercitio forti, si non est ei praesens balneum, donec calefiat membrum.	Then introduce him into a bath or bind him with warm water on his leg until it becomes red and the veins swell: or exercise himself vigorously if there is no bath available, until the member warms up.
Deinde seca cutem in directo uenae sectione per longitudinem: aut in ultimo eius apud genu, aut in inferiori parte eius apud calcaneum.	Then cut the skin along the direction of the vein's incision by its length: or at the end of it near the knee, or at the lower part of it near the heel.
Deinde aperi cutem cum uncinis, et excoria uenam ab omni parte, donec appareat sensui: et est apud apparitionem eius, quod uides eam rubeam ad nigredinem decliuem.	Then open the cut with a hook and remove the vein from every part until it appears to the sense: and it is at its appearance when you see it turn red to black.
Cum ergo uadit ex cute, uides eam albam quasi sit chorda.	When therefore it goes out from the skin, you see it as white as if it were a string.
Deinde intromitte sub ea Radium, donec quando eleuatur et egreditur de cute: suspende eam cum uncino caeco, leni.	Then insert under it the needle until it is elevated and goes out of the skin: suspend it with a blind hook, gently.
Deinde seca sectionem aliam prope illam sectionem tribus digitis.	Then cut off another section near that section, three fingers away.
Deinde excoria cutem a superiori parte uenae, donec appareat.	Then scrape the skin from the upper part of the vein until it appears.
Deinde eleua eam cum Radiis sicut fecisti, et suspende eam cum uncino alio, sicut fecisti in primis.	Then lift it up with the needle as you did, and suspend it with another hook, just as you did at first.
Deinde seca sectionem aliam, aut sectiones plures, si indiges illo.	Then cut off another section, or several sections if needed.
Deinde eleua, et incide ipsam ultima sectione apud calcaneum.	Then lift it up and cut the last section at the heelbone.
Deinde extrahe eam ad sectionem quae est supra eam.	Then pull it out to the section that is above it.
Et fac illud, donec extrahas eam ex sectione quae est superior, uel altior sectionibus omnibus, donec quando egreditur tota: tunc incide eam.	And do that until you pull it out from the upper or higher sections, until when it is entirely gone; then cut it.
Si autem non obedit tibi ad extrahendum, et eleuandum: tunc intromitte acum cum filo forti duplo, et liga eam, et extrahe ipsam: aut intromitte sub ea Radium: et reuolue manum tuam ad omnem partem, donec egrediatur.	But if it does not comply with you to pull out and lift up: then insert a strong double thread needle into it, and tie it, and pull it out; or insert under it the needle, and turn your hand around all sides until it comes out.
Et caue, ne incidatur.	And beware, lest it be cut.
Nam si incidatur, fit difficile tibi eleuare eam ualde, et ingreditur super infirmum ex ea nocumentum.	For if it is cut, it becomes difficult for you to lift it up very much, and harm comes from it to the patient.
Cum ergo extraxeris eam totam: tunc pone super locum uulnerum lanam submersam in uino et oleo rosato, aut oleo: et cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	When therefore you have pulled it out entirely: then place over the wound a soaked cloth in wine and rose oil, or oil: and care for it until it is healed.
Quod si Vitis est contracta, habens tortuositatem cui sit inuolutio ad partes, et non est sicut diximus secundum rectitudinem: tunc oportet ut findas super eam ad omnem partem tortuositatis eius, et loca inuolutionis ipsius.	If the vein is contracted and twisted, having a curvature that wraps around to the parts, and it is not as we said according to straightness: then you must cut above it on all sides of its twisting and wrapping.
Deinde suspende eam cum uncinis, donec eleues eam totam: et caue apud sectionem tuam super eam ne incidas uenam, aut uulneres: nam difficile fiet super te eleuare, uel extrahere eam.	Then suspend it with hooks, until you lift it up entirely: and beware at your section above it not to cut the vein or wound; for it will be difficult for you to lift or pull it out.
Conserua ergo prudentiam tuam.	Therefore preserve your prudence.
Forma Incidentis quo sanatur Vitis.	The manner in which a wound is healed.
Forma Vncini caeci.	The form of binding the blind eye.
Non est ei curuitas sicut reliquis Vncinis, neque est acutae extremitatis, ut non uulneret uenam: et est grossae flectuositatis, lenis: quoniam si esset subtilis, incideret uenam subtilitate sua: imo sit ei superflua grossitudo, sicut diximus.	There is no curvature to it like the other bandages, nor is it sharp-edged so as not to wound the vein; and it has a thickened flexuousness, gentle. For if it were thin, it would cut through the vein because of its own subtlety. Indeed, there is excessive thickness to it, as we have said.
De extractione Venae cruris.	On the removal of the vein in the leg.
Caput XCIII.	Chapter 93.
Haec Vena generatur in cruribus in terris calidis, sicut Alizegi, et terra Arabum, et in terris aridis, calidis, paucae teneritatis, id est, in quibus non nascitur herba, neque arbor.	This vein is generated in the legs on hot earth, such as in Alysus and Arabian land, and in dry, hot lands of little fertility, that is to say, where no herb nor tree grows.
Et fortasse generatur in locis aliis corporis praeter crura.	And perhaps it is generated in other parts of the body besides the legs.
Et generatio quidem eius est a putrefactione quae accidit sub cute, sicut accidunt intra corpora serpentes et uermes ascarides, et uermes generati inter cutem et carnem.	And its generation indeed is from the putrefaction that occurs beneath the skin, just as it happens within the bodies of serpents and ascarid worms, and worms generated between the skin and flesh.
Et signum incaeptionis euentus huius Venae est, quod accidit in crure inflammatio uehemens.	And the sign of its beginning is that which occurs in the leg, namely a violent inflammation.
Deinde uesicatur locus.	Then the place is swollen.
Deinde incipit Vena exire ex loco illius uesicationis, quasi sit radix plantae, aut animal.	Then the vein begins to emerge from that swollen place, as if it were the root of a plant or an animal.
Cum ergo apparet ex ea extremitas eius, tunc oportet ut inuoluas super ipsam frustum plumbi, cuius pondus sit ex drachma keil, usque ad drachmas II et noda ipsam: et dimitte plumbum suspensum ex crure.	When then the end of it appears from that vein, then you must wrap a piece of lead around it, weighing one and a half drachmas keil, up to two and a half drachmas, and suspend the lead from the leg.
Quotiens ergo egreditur ex ea aliquid ad exteriora, inuolue illud in plumbo, et noda illud.	Whenever then something emerges from it into the outside, wrap that thing in lead and bind it.
Quod si prolongatur multum, tunc incide partem eius, et inuolue residuum.	If it is prolonged too much, then cut off a part of it and wrap up the remainder.
Et non incidas eam radicitus antequam egrediatur tota.	And do not cut it at its root until it has emerged entirely.
Quoniam si incidis, contrahitur, et ingreditur in carnem: et facit accidere apostema, et putredinem in loco, et ulcus malum.	Since it is cut, it constricts and enters into flesh: and makes a pustule to occur, and putridity in the place, and an evil ulcer.
Quapropter oportet, ut suauiter tractetur, et extrahatur paulatim, donec egrediatur ex ultimo sui, et non remaneat ex ea aliquid in corpore: et ex hac quidem Vena egreditur in quibusdam hominibus quod est in longitudine sua quinque palmorum et decem.	Therefore it is necessary that it be treated gently and drawn out gradually, until it emerges from the last part of itself and nothing remains from it in the body: and from this very vein, in some people, there emerges something which is five palms long and ten in length.
Et iam peruenit ad me, quia exiuit uiro ex XX palmis.	And now it has reached me, because it emerged from a man who was twenty palms tall.
Si autem inciditur tibi in hora medicationis tuae: tunc intromitte radium in foramine eius, et perfora eam foramine longo, cum corpore, donec euacuetur totum quod est in ea ex materia: et administra putrefactionem loci cum medicinis diebus aliquot.	But if it happens to you during the time of your medication: then insert a thread into its opening and pierce it with a long drill, along with the body, until what is inside it is emptied out from the material: and administer putrefaction to the place with medicines for several days.
Deinde cura ipsum curatione apostematum.	Then care for it by treating pustules.
Et haec quidem Vena quandoque habet ramos multos, praecipue quando apparet in iunctura pedis, aut in pede ipso: et accidunt ei orificia multa, et egreditur ex omni orificio ramus.	And this vein sometimes has many branches, especially when it appears at the junction of the foot or in the foot itself: and openings occur many times, and a branch emerges from every opening.
Cura ergo ipsam, sicut diximus in diuisione, et cum eo quod praemissum est.	So cure it as we said in the division, and along with what was previously mentioned.
¶ De sectione super Vermes generatos sub cute, et dicitur Aegritudo bouina.	Chapter on cutting off worms generated under the skin, and is called Bovine Distress.
Caput XCIIII.	Book 94.
Haec Aegritudo nominatur in quadam terra apud nos Aegritudo bouina: propterea, quia multotiens accidit bouibus, et est uermis paruus unus, qui nascitur inter cutem et carnem.	This Distress is called Bovine Distress in a certain land among us, because it often happens to oxen, and there is one small worm that is born between the skin and flesh.
Et uadit in corpore toto, ascendendo et descendendo: et ostenditur sensui apud ambulationem eius de membro ad membrum, donec disrumpit ubicumque disrumpit in cute locum, et egreditur.	And it moves through the entire body, ascending and descending: and is shown to the sense by its walking from member to member, until it bursts wherever it bursts through the skin at a place, and emerges.
Et generatio eius est ex putredine quorundam humorum.	And its generation is from the putrefaction of certain humors.
Sicut accidunt uermes et serpentes, id est, lumbrici, et ascarides in uentre.	Just as worms and serpents, that is, lice and ascarids, occur in the belly.
Et timetur ex malicia eius.	And beware of his wickedness.
Quia quando ipse uadit in corpore, et eleuatur ad caput, et peruenit ad locum: tunc fortasse aperit in eo, et egreditur, et destruit oculum: et accidit illud multotiens.	Because when he goes into the body and is elevated to the head and reaches a place; then perhaps he opens up in it, and emerges, and destroys the eye: and that happens many times.
Cum ergo uis curare eum, et extrahere ipsum, tunc non fit illud nisi apud ambulationem eius, et apparitionem ipsius sensui.	So when you wish to cure him and extract it, then that is not done except by his movement and appearance to the sense.
Oportet ergo, ut stringas quod est supra eum, et quod est sub eo cum ligamento constrictione forti.	Therefore, you must tighten what is above him, and what is below him with a strong binding ligament.
Deinde seca super ipsum, et extrahe eum.	Then cut above him, and extract him.
Quod si profundatur in carne, et non inuenis ipsum: tunc pone super locum cauterium cum igne, donec moriatur.	And if it penetrates into the flesh and you do not find it: then place a cautery with fire above the spot until it dies.
Et maius quod timetur, est corruptio eius, qua corrumpit oculum, sicut diximus.	And even greater than that which is to be feared, is its corruption, by which it corrupts the eye, as we said.
Si autem uides eum iam peruenisse in capite prope oculum, tunc stringe sub eo supercilium strictura bona.	But if you see him having reached the head near the eye, then bind the eyebrow above it with a good tightening.
Deinde seca super ipsum, et extrahe eum.	Then cut above him, and extract him.
Et oportet ut utatur infirmus mundificatione sui corporis, cum medicinis soluentibus humores putridos malos.	And it is necessary for the patient to use a purification of his body with medicines that dissolve bad, putrid humors.
Et caueat sibi a cibis generantibus putrefactionem.	And beware of foods that cause putrefaction.
¶ De sectione super aegritudinem Nakir.	About the section for Nakir's sickness.
Caput XCV.	Head 95.
Haec aegritudo nominatur in terra nostra Nakir: et est dolor qui accidit in quibusdam membris: deinde permutatur de membro ad membrum.	This sickness is called Nakir on our earth, and it is a pain that occurs in certain members, then changes from member to member.
Et ego quidem iam uidi ipsum, secundum quod narro tibi.	And I myself have already seen him, according to what I tell you.
Vocatus sum ad mulierem infirmam in quibusdam uillis.	I was called to a sick woman in some villages.
Et detexit brachium suum, et uidi inflationem paruam in uena funis brachii.	And she showed me her arm and I saw a small swelling in the vein of the arm.
Et postquam remansi hora una, uidi unam inflationem incedere cum focili, sicut incedit uermis, ascendendo ad humerum eius uelocius quam esse potest: ut sit sicut argentum uiuum, quando currit de loco ad locum.	And after I stayed for one hour, I saw one swelling walking with a pustule, like a worm, ascending to her shoulder faster than it can be, so that it is like quicksilver when it runs from place to place.
Recessit ergo dolor ex illo loco, et fixus est in humero.	Therefore the pain departed from that place and was fixed on the shoulder.
Deinde sedi hora una, et cucurrit in reliquum corpus, donec perueniret in brachium aliud.	Then one hour passed and it ran through the rest of the body until it reached another arm.
Deinde narrauit mihi, quia reuoluebatur in toto corpore suo, secundum quod uidi.	Then he told me that his whole body was revolving according to what I saw.
Miratus sum ergo de uelocitate permutationis eius de membro ad membrum.	I therefore gazed in amazement at the speed of its change from member to member.
Et ego quidem ante illud non uideram hanc aegritudinem oculis meis taliter secundum hunc modum.	And I myself had not seen this illness with my own eyes in such a manner before that.
Verumtamen uidi multos, qui inueniunt dolorem permutari de membro ad membrum: et non uidi ipsum oculis, sicut uidi eum in muliere.	But I have seen many others who find pain being transferred from member to member; and I did not see him with my own eyes as I saw him in the woman.
Et ego non cogito illud esse, nisi quod est propterea, quod mulier fuit ex illis qui sunt ex uillis sicci corporis detectarum uenarum: hinc ergo apparet sensui illa uentositas permutata.	And I do not think it is otherwise, except that the woman was one of those who are found to be from dry bodies detected through veins; therefore this apparent windiness appears to sense as having been changed.
Et est necesse, ut non appareant secundum hanc rationem in illis qui sunt deliciosi, et corporibus humidis, occultarum uenarum.	And it is necessary that they do not appear according to this reason in those who are luxurious and have bodies that are moist with hidden veins.
Cum ergo uis curationem eius, et sentit patiens illud dolorem: tunc si est apparens tibi oculo, sicut diximus, tunc stringe supra ipsum, et sub ipso uelociter: et seca supra ipsum, donec egrediatur illa uentositas coartata: et cauteriza locum.	When therefore you wish to cure him and the patient feels that pain: then if it appears to your eye as we said, then tie above him quickly and below him quickly: and cut above him until that windiness is choked out: and cauterize the place.
Si autem non uides ipsum oculis tuis: tunc cura ipsum cum excussione corporis, et cum eo quod expellit uentositates, et carminat eas cum pillulis foetidis, et pillulis de serapino, et similibus.	But if you do not see it with your own eyes: then cure him by excision of the body and with that which drives out windiness, and purge them with pungent pills and pills of asarum and similar things.
¶ De extractione Sagittarum.	Of the Extraction of Arrows.
Caput XCVI.	Chapter 96.
Sagittae diuersificantur secundum species suas, et secundum loca in quibus cadunt ex corpore.	Arrows are differentiated according to their own kinds and according to the places where they fall from the body.
Earum uero diuersitas est: quoniam ex eis sunt quae habent cuspides magnos, et paruos: et concauae, et surdae.	And their variety is this: because some of them have large points and small ones: and concave and convex ones.
Et ex eis sunt quae habent tres angulos.	And among them are those that have three angles.
Et ex eis quibus sunt linguae.	And among them are tongues.
Et ex eis quibus sunt astellae.	And among them are stars.
Illae uero quae sunt secundum membra in quibus cadunt, est secundum duos modos.	However, those that fall according to limbs are two ways.
Aut enim membra sunt ex membris principalibus concauis, sicut cerebrum, et cor, et epar, et pulmo, et renes, et intestina, et uesica, et eis similia.	For either limbs are from primary concave members, such as the brain, and heart, and liver, and lung, and kidneys, and intestines, and bladder, and like things.
Quando ergo cadit in aliquo horum membrorum, et apparent tibi signa mortis, quae ego narro tibi post, tunc oportet ut deuites extractionem illius sagittae ex eis, nam mors consequitur illum in quo est, in pluribus dispositionibus.	So when it falls into one of these limbs and signs of death appear to you, which I will tell you after, then it is necessary to remove the arrow from them, for death follows that in which it is, in many dispositions.
Et quando non apparent tibi ista signa mala, et sagitta non est absconsa in profunditate membri, tunc extrahe ipsam, et cura uulnus.	And when these bad signs do not appear to you, and the arrow is not hidden in the depth of a member, then remove it and care for the wound.
Ex signis enim cerebri quando cadit in eo sagitta, et penetrat os, et egreditur siphac quod est super cerebrum, est: quoniam accidunt ex illo soda uehemens, et scotomia, et uertigo, et rubedo in oculis, et inflatio, et rubedo linguae, et spasmus, et permixtio intellectus, et uomitus cholerae.	From the signs of the brain when an arrow falls into it and penetrates to the skull and exits above the brain, there are: a swelling or inflammation, blindness, vertigo, redness in the eyes, puffing up, redness of the tongue, spasms, and confusion of intellect, and vomiting with cholera.
Et fortasse egreditur sanguis ex naribus, aut auribus.	And perhaps blood will exit through the nose or ears.
Et fortasse abscinditur sermo, et destruitur uox.	And perhaps speech is cut off, and the voice is destroyed.
Et egreditur ex loco uulneris humiditas alba similis pulti.	And a white liquid similar to pus exits from the wound location.
Et exit ex eo simile aquositati carnis.	And it exits like a fluid of flesh.
Si ergo apparent tibi ista signa, tunc abstine a curatione, et extrahe sagittam si non egreditur.	If then these signs appear to you, then refrain from treatment and remove the arrow if it does not exit.
Signa autem sagittae quando cadit in corde, sunt: quod ipsa est prope mammillam sinistram: et sentit cum ea quasi ipsa sit fixa in re dura, non in re uacua.	The signs of the arrow when it falls into the heart are: that it is near the left breast; and one feels with it as if it were fixed in a hard substance, not in an empty space.
Et fortasse sagittae est motus similis motui pulsus: et currit ex uulnere sanguis niger.	And perhaps the arrow's motion is similar to the pulse's motion: and blood flows black from the wound.
Et sequitur illud frigus extremitatum, et sudor frigidus, et syncopis.	And it follows coldness of extremities, and cold sweat, and congestion.
Scias ergo, quod mors descendit procul dubio.	You should therefore know that death certainly approaches.
Et signum sagittae quando uulnerat pulmonem, est exitus sanguinis spumosi ex uulnere: et uasa quae sequuntur collum, apostematur, et mutatur color infirmi.	And the sign of an arrow wound that wounds the lung is when bloody frothy discharge flows from the wound. And the veins which follow the neck become inflamed and change the complexion of the patient.
Et expirat spiritum magnum, altum: et quaerit attractionem aeris frigidi.	And he breathes out a great, high-sounding sigh: and seeks to draw in cold air.
Quod si cadat sagitta in uelamen, quod est in pectore: tunc est prope costas paruas: et fit anhelitus magnus cum dolore uehementi, cum suspirio: et mouentur omnia membra humerorum.	For if the arrow falls into the vellum that is in the chest: then it is near to small ribs: and a great panting occurs with severe pain, with sighing: and all the limbs of the shoulders are moved.
Et si cadat sagitta in stomachum, tunc fortasse egreditur ex uulnere ex cibo aliquid indigestum.	And if the arrow falls into the stomach, then perhaps something undigested from food will come out of the wound.
Et si cadit sagitta in Ventrem, et figitur in eo: egreditur aliquid stercoris ex uulnere, aut zirbum, aut intestinum quod iam disruptum est.	And if the arrow falls into the belly and sticks in it: something of dung will come out of the wound, or pus, or an intestine that is already broken.
Non est ergo spes in curatione eius, neque in extractione sagittae.	Therefore there is no hope for his cure, nor for extracting the arrow.
Quod si sagitta cadat in Vesicam, et egrediatur urina: et procedit ex ea aliquid ad exteriora, et fortior sit dolor super infirmum: tunc scias, quia est mortale.	For if the arrow falls into the bladder and urine flows out: and something proceeds from it to the outside, and the pain is much greater over the patient: then you should know that it is mortal.
Reliqua autem membra, sicut facies, et collum, et guttur, et spatula, et adiutorium, et spondiles dorsi, et furcula, et coxa, et crus, et eis similia ex membris saluantur secundum plures dispositiones: quando non inuenit sagitta arteriam, aut neruum: et non est sagitta uenenosa.	The remaining limbs, such as the face, neck, throat, palate, and shoulder-girdle, and similar parts of the members, are saluted according to many dispositions when the arrow does not find an artery or nerve, and the arrow is not poisonous.
Et ego narro tibi quod uidi de esse harum sagittarum, ut significes per illud super curationem tuam.	And I tell you what I have seen to be of these arrows, so that you may signify through it above your own cure.
Quod est, quia cuidam uiro cecidit sagitta in lachrymali oculi eius, in radice nasi.	Which is this: for to a certain man an arrow fell into the tear duct of his eye, at the root of his nose.
Extraxi ergo eam ipsi ex parte altera, sub adipe auris eius: et sanatus est, et non accidit ei in oculo eius nocumentum.	So I extracted it from the other side, under the fat of his ear; and he was healed, and no harm came to his eye.
Et extraxi sagittam aliam Iudaeo, quae cecidit ei in adipe oculi sui sub palpebra inferiori: et sagitta iam occultata erat, et non consecutus sum ex ea nisi extremitatem paruam eius, cum qua adhaeret in ligno suo: et erat sagitta magna ex sagittis arcuum Turcorum, cum ferro leni, in qua non sunt aures.	And I extracted another arrow from the Jew, which had fallen upon his eyelid under the lower eyelid; and the arrow was already hidden, and I could not obtain more than its small tip with which it adhered to the wood: and it was a large arrow of the Turkish bows, with a soft iron point, without ears.
Sanatus est ergo Iudaeus, et non accidit in oculo eius accidens malum.	The Jew was therefore healed, and the evil occurrence did not happen to his eye.
Et extraxi sagittam aliam ex gutture Christiani.	And I extracted another arrow from the throat of a Christian.
Et erat sagitta arabica, et est illa cui sunt aures.	And it was an Arab arrow, and it is that one which has ears.
Secui ergo super ipsam inter duas guidegi: et iam submersa erat in gutture eius.	I then fastened a cloth over her between two strips of linen: and now she had already sunk into his throat.
Subtiliatus sum ergo cum ea, donec extraxi eam: et sanatus est Christianus.	I therefore carefully pulled on it until I extracted it: and the Christian was healed.
Et extraxi sagittam aliam uiro quae ceciderat in uentre eius: et cogitauimus, quia moreretur ex ea.	And I extracted another arrow from a man which had fallen into his belly: and we thought that he would die from it.
Postquam ergo praeterierunt ei triginta dies, et non mutatum est super eum aliquid ex dispositionibus eius, secui super sagittam: et ingeniaui super eam, et extraxi eam: et sanatus est, et non accidit ei accidens malum.	Afterwards, then, thirty days had passed over him and nothing in his condition had changed, I covered the arrow with a cloth; and I pulled on it, and extracted it: and he was healed, and no evil occurrence happened to him.
Et uidi uirum cui cecidit sagitta in dorso eius, et consolidatum est uulnus super eam.	And I saw a man upon whom an arrow had fallen on his back, and the wound was set over it.
Postquam ergo fuit post septem annos, exiuit sagitta in radice coxae eius.	Afterwards, then, seven years had passed, the arrow came out through the root of his hip.
Et uidi mulierem cui cecidit in uentre suo sagitta, et consolidatum est uulnus super eam, et remansit sagitta intra ipsam: et non mutata est ex dispositionibus eius aliqua, et mulier non inuenit ei nocumentum in aliqua ex operationibus suis naturalibus.	And I saw a woman upon whom an arrow had fallen into her womb, and the wound was set over it, and the arrow remained within her: and nothing in her condition changed, and the woman did not find any harm from her natural bodily functions.
Et uidi uirum alium, cui cecidit sagitta in facie sua: et consolidatum est uulnus, et remansit, non inueniens ei multum dolorem: et similia istis multa.	And I saw another man upon whom an arrow had fallen on his face: and the wound was set, and remained, not finding much pain for him: and similar things to these many.
Et extraxi sagittam uiro ex principibus Regis, quae ceciderat ei in medio nasi sui, et iam declinauerat ad partem dextram parumper: et occultata erat sagitta tota.	And I extracted an arrow from the king's most trusted servants, which had fallen into his nose and was now leaning slightly to the right side; and the arrow was entirely hidden.
Vocatus sum ergo ad curationem eius post casum sagittae usque ad tres dies.	I was called therefore to cure him after the fall of the arrow for three days.
Inueni ergo uulnus sagittae strictum ualde.	I found then the wound from the arrow to be very tightly constricted.
Inquisiui ergo eam cum tenta subtili, et non sensi eam: et ipse quidem inueniebat punctionem et dolorem sub aure sua ex parte dextra.	I then probed it with a fine probe and did not find it; but he himself found the puncture and pain under his ear on the right side.
Speraui ergo, quod erat illa punctio ex extremitate sagittae.	I therefore expected that the puncture was from the end of the arrow.
Emplastraui ergo locum cum emplastro in quo erat uirtus attractiua, et digestiua, confidens apud me, quod apostemaretur locus, et appareret mihi signum sagittae, ut secarem super eam: et non accidit in loco accidens significans quod sagitta consecuta sit locum.	I then applied a poultice to the place with a poultice that had attractive and digestive power, trusting in myself, since I believed the spot would suppurate and a sign of the arrow would appear for me to cut above it: and no accident occurred in the place indicating that the arrow had reached the location.
Assiduaui ergo cum emplastro super eum diebus multis: et non accidit accidens, et consolidatum est uulnus interim: et remansit infirmus de extractione eius spacio dierum, donec sensit sagittam die quodam intra nasum suum.	I therefore applied the poultice to him daily for many days: and no accident occurred, and the wound was consolidated in the meantime: and he remained weak from its removal until he felt the arrow on a certain day inside his nose.
Et narrauit mihi illud.	And he told me that.
Posui ergo super illud uulnus medicinam acutam, corrosiuam diebus multis, donec apertum est: et cum tenta tentaui ipsum, et sensi extremitatem sagittae subtilem quae adhaeret in ligno.	I then applied sharp and corroding medicine to that wound daily for many days, until it was opened: and when I probed him with a probe, I felt the subtle end of the arrow which adhered to the wood.
Deinde addidi in apertione uulneris per illam medicinam acutam, donec apparuit nobis uisibiliter extremitas sagittae: et praeteriit mihi cum eo spacium temporis circiter quatuor menses.	Then I added to the opening of the wound through that sharp medicine until the end of the arrow appeared visibly before us; and after it had passed with him, a period of about four months elapsed.
Deinde postquam amplificatum est uulnus, et possible fuit mihi intromittere forcipes in ipsam, et mouere ipsam, et non obediuit ad exitum: tunc non cessaui subtiliare, et ingeniare super eam cum modis ingeniorum, donec coepi super eam die quodam cum forcipibus decenter factis, secundum quod ueniet forma eorum in fine capituli, donec extraxi eam.	Then after the wound had been enlarged and it was possible for me to insert forceps into it, and move it, but it did not yield to exit: then I did not cease to file and shape it above it with various techniques, until on a certain day I began to work on it with well-made forceps, according to the form they would take at the end of the chapter, until I extracted it.
Deinde restauraui uulnus.	Then I restored the wound.
Et medici quidem iudicant, quod cartilago nasi non restauratur.	And indeed doctors judge that the nasal cartilage is not restored.
Restauraui ergo ipsam, et consolidatum est uulnus, et sanatus est infirmas sanitate integra: nec nocuit ei aliquid omnino.	I therefore restored it and the wound was consolidated and the patient was healed with a complete and unbroken recovery; nor did anything harm him at all.
Et ego narro tibi qualitatem extractionis quarundam sagittarum: ut ponas illud regulam et significationem super illud quod non dixi.	And I will tell you the quality of extracting certain arrows: so that you put it to the rule and significance over what I did not say.
Quoniam partes huius artis et distinctiones earum non comprehenduntur cum narratione: neque comprehendit illud liber, et artifex prudens comparat cum pauco super multum: et cum eo quod est paesens, super illud quod est absens: et inuenit operationem nouam, et instrumentum nouum apud descensus rerum extranearum huius artis quando accidunt.	Because the parts of this art and their distinctions are not comprehended with narration: nor does that book comprehend it; a wise craftsman compares what is little to much: and with what is present, over what is absent: and he finds a new operation and a new instrument among external events of this art when they happen.
Dico ergo, quod sagittae non egrediuntur ex membris quibus sunt fixae, nisi secundum duos modos.	I say, that arrows do not emerge from the members to which they are fixed, unless according to two modes.
Aut per attractionem ex loco ex quo intrauit.	Or through attraction from the place from which it entered.
Aut contrario partis alterius.	Or contrary to the other part of the opposite side.
Et illa quae egreditur unde intrauit, aut est sagitta procedens in loco carnoso: et attrahitur, et egreditur.	And that which emerges from where it entered is either an arrow proceeding into a fleshy place and is attracted and emerges.
Quod si non obedit ad exitum ex hora in qua cadit: tunc oportet ut dimittas ipsam aliquot diebus, donec putrefiat caro quae est in circumitu eius: et alleuietur attractio eius, et eius egressio.	What if it does not obey the exit from the hour when it falls: then you must let it go for some days until the flesh that is around it putrefies: and its attraction and emergence will be alleviated.
Et similiter si figitur in osse, et non obedit tibi ad exitum, tunc dimitte ipsam etiam aliquot diebus: et itera eam cum attractione et motione omni die, donec egreditur.	And similarly if it is fixed in bone and does not obey you to exit, then let it go again for some days: and bring it back with attraction and motion every day until it emerges.
Quod si non obedit tibi ad exitum post dies, tunc oportet ut perfores in circumitu sagittae in ipso osse ab omni parte cum terebro subtili, donec amplificentur sagittae.	What if it does not obey you to exit after days, then it is necessary that you pierce the surrounding area of the arrow in the bone from all sides with a fine chisel until the arrows are widened.
Deinde attrahe eam, et extrahe ipsam.	Then attract it and pull it out.
Si autem sagitta est fixa in capitis osse, et iam processit in uno uentrium cerebri, et apparent ex infirmo quaedam illorum accidentium quae dixi: tunc abstine ab attractione sagittae, et dimitte eam, donec aequetur esse eius post dies.	If however the arrow is fixed in the bone of the skull and has already progressed into one of the ventricles of the brain, and certain of those symptoms which I mentioned appear from the patient: then abstain from attracting the arrow and let it go until its state is equal after days.
Nam si sagitta peruenit ad sifach, tunc mors non prolongatur ei.	If an arrow reaches the sifach, then death is not prolonged for him.
Et si sagitta non est fixa, nisi in corpore ossis tantum, et non penetrat usque ad sifach: et remanet infirmus aliquot diebus, et non accidit ei ex illis accidentibus aliquid: tunc ingenia in attractione sagittae et extractione eius.	And if the arrow is not fixed except in the body of a bone only and does not penetrate to the sifach, and he remains infirm for several days, and nothing happens to him from those accidents: then one must attend to drawing out the arrow and extracting it.
Si autem est fixa ualde, et non obedit tibi ad attractionem: tunc administra terebella in circumitu sagittae, sicut narraui tibl: deinde cura locum, donec sanetur.	But if it is firmly fixed and does not yield to your attempts at extraction: then apply terebinthine around the arrow, as I have told you: afterwards take care of the wound until it heals.
Si autem Sagitta iam absconsa est in loco corporis, et occultatur et absconditur a sensu: tunc inquire eam cum tenta.	But if the arrow is already concealed in the body and hidden from sense: then seek it out with probes.
Si autem sentis eam, tunc attrahe eam cum quibusdam instrumentis quae conueniunt attractioni eius.	But if you feel it, then draw it out with some instruments that are suitable for its extraction.
Si autem non potes super eam, propter constrictionem uulneris, et propter longitudinem sagittae in profundo: et non est illic os, neque neruus, neque uena: tunc finde super eam, donec amplificetur uulnus, et sit possibile extrahere sagittam.	But if you are unable to draw it out because of the constriction of the wound and the length of the arrow in deep tissue, and there is no bone, nerve, or vein: then find a way to enlarge the wound until it becomes possible to extract the arrow.
Quod si sunt ei aures quibus teneatur, tunc libera carnem fixam in eis ab omni parte, omni ingenio quo potes illud, et ingenia, si non potest super euasionem carnis in fractura aurium, et contorsione earum, donec euadat.	But if there are ears which hold it fast: then free the fixed flesh from all parts, by any means you can, and use instruments, if it cannot be removed by cutting through the ears, or by their fracture and twisting, until it comes out.
Et tu quando administras extractionem Sagittae, in quocumque loco est, tunc utere contorsione manus tuae, cum forficibus ad partes omnes, donec facias eam euadere: et subtilia ultima subtilitate, ut non frangatur Sagita, et fiat difficilis tibi attractio eius, et ipsius extractio.	And when you are administering the extraction of the arrow, wherever it is, then use the twisting motion of your hand, with forceps on all parts, until you make it come out: and with the finest subtlety, so that the arrow does not break and its extraction becomes difficult for you.
Quod si non potes super eam ex hora una, tunc dimitte eam diebus aliquot, donec putrefiant quae sunt in circumitu eius.	But if you are unable to extract it at one hour, then leave it for several days, until the things that surround it have putrified.
Deinde itera eam: alleuietur enim tuncia Si uero contrarietatem tibi facit fluxus sanguinis, tunc administra quod diximus ex curatione in capitulo suo: et custodi uirtutem tuam ab incisione uenae, aut nerui, aut chordae.	Then retry to extract it: for it will be eased. If however, opposition is made by a flow of blood, then administer what we said in its own chapter on cure: and take care to preserve your strength from cutting the vein, or nerve, or cord.
Et administra ingenium omni modo quo tibi possibile est euasionis Sagittae: et sit illud cum facilitate, et tranquillitate, uel tarditate, et firmitate, sicut narraui tibi.	And administer the skill of surgery in every way possible to you, with ease, and calmness, or slowness, and firmness, just as I told you.
Et oportet, ut facias cum trahis Sagittam, ut infirmus sit secundum figuram, secundum quam fuit apud casum Sagittae in ipso.	And it is necessary that you do so when pulling out the arrow, making the patient conform to the shape as he was in the case of being shot with the arrow itself.
Quoniam est magis iuuatiuum.	Because it is more beneficial.
Si autem non est tibi possibile illud, tunc administra quod tibi est possibile ex figuris.	But if this is not possible for you, then administer what is possible to you from the shapes.
Sagitta autem quae egreditur ex contrario partis alterius, aut iam procedit ex ea aliquid ad exteriora: aut facit gibbositatem extremitas Sagittae per sensum ex superiore parte cutis propinquae, et uides eam eminentem: seca ergo super eam, et sit sectio secundum quantitatem quod capiant in ea forcipes.	But the arrow that comes out from the opposite part of another, or has already proceeded something to the exterior from it; or makes a swelling at the tip of the arrow by sensation from above on the neighboring skin, and you see it protruding: therefore cut above it, and let the incision be according to the size that forceps can take in it.
Deinde attrahe eam: ipsa namque fit facilis ad exitum.	Then draw it out: for it is easy to come out by itself.
Si uero retinetur in osse, tunc torque manum tuam secundum rotunditatem, donec imprimat Sagitta in osse, et amplificet sibiipsi: deinde trahe ipsam.	But if it is retained in the bone, then twist your hand according to the roundness, until the arrow stamps itself in the bone and makes room for itself: then draw it out.
Et si non: dimitte eam diebus aliquot: deinde itera eam, donec egrediatur.	And if not: let it be for a few days: then try to pull it out until it comes out.
Quod si lignum Sagittae est in ea, tunc impelle ipsam cum eo.	Which if the wood of the arrow is stuck in it, then push it with that.
Si autem cecidit lignum, et uis administrare impulsionem: tunc intromitte ad eam instrumentum concauum, ut ingrediatur concauitas eius in caudam Sagittae: deinde impelle eam cum ipso.	But if the wood has fallen and you wish to administer a push: then introduce into it an instrument with a concave shape, so that its concavity enters the tail of the arrow: then push it with it.
Si autem Sagita est concaua, tunc impelle eam cum instrumento intrante in ipsam.	But if the arrow is hollow, then push it with the instrument entering into it.
Sagitta enim alleuiatur per illud.	For the arrow is eased by that.
